topics.coverage_text:
So, let's go ahead and do this.
And get the specifications for this power amplifier.
To start it, let's talk about the power, because that's one of the most important functions of any power amplifier is actually to get the small signal that we receive at the inputs.
And from a, say, for example, from a pre-amplifier, and then basically get a power gain and feed a very low impedance load.
So, since that's one of the main functions of a power amplifier, the power that I chose for this amplifier is 25 watts.
Reason is, for personal use and in home applications, you're not going to need more than 25 watts.
Basically, that's ample enough power.
And if you have decent speakers, which are efficient, delivering 25 watts to them, they should be able to convert that to a very impressive sound.
And, like I said, in home environment.
So, that's why I chose 25 watts.
And the power amplifier should also handle very low impedance load.
For example, for this application, I have chosen it to handle at least 4 ohms.
Minimum 4 ohms.
It should be able to handle 8 ohms speakers as well.
But 4 ohms is the load that we should be able to handle.
The THD for this amplifier, of course, is an important specification as well.
It needs to be less than 0.1% at full power output.
And at 20 kHz.
And as we'll talk about why this specification is necessary, why I'm putting the frequency.
But, basically, the total harmonic distortion of this power amplifier should be less than or equal to 0.1% at full load output power.
And, you know, we could go, you know, play around with the amplifier to actually reduce this to much lower levels.
But 0.1% should be enough for the purposes of this video.
And we should achieve, we should be able to achieve this and work towards to make this amplifier have that much distortion at the full output power at 20 kHz.
Next is the, another important specification that we need to cover is the frequency response.
The frequency response of this amplifier should be from 20 to 20 kHz.
This is normal for audio purposes because our hearing, human hearing, is in this range.

the RMS voltage squared divided by the load impedance, right?
